The machine is equipped with a system that can measure the fertiliser quantity in real time. This system is called the ISO control system and it uses the ISOBUS communication protocol.
The spreader measures the amount of fertiliser being spread by means of weight sensors, which are located on the spreading discs. The computer compares these values to the set application rate and corrects as needed with further opening or closing the dosing unit.
The tractor's electronics or an extra (GPS) sensor measures the current required driving speed and localisation.
The working width and the start/stop time is controlled by field boundaries and headlands. Field data imported from a new management system or a newly created field boundary is used for this purpose.

The machine is equipped with an ISOBUS communication system and a control box, which are used to operate the spreader. The tractor must have a valve for operating the machine accessories.
A valve is required for the lights.
Control system
The control system of the spreader in combination with the IsoMatch control box also transmits the application rate and working width used back to the external system.
The external system and the control system of a spreader with an IsoMatch control box communicate through a serial port with an RS 232 connection. This connection is located at the back of the control box. The occupation of pins in the 9-point RS 232 plug and the settings required are given in
 the user manual of the IsoMatch control box.
The tractor must have a valve to operate the machine accessories.

Required hydraulic valves

The coupling shaft provided is too long for most types of tractors
The coupling shaft must be cut to the correct length before connecting it to the tractor. A coupling shaft that is too long could lead to serious damage to the machine and the tractor.

 paragraph »Shortening the coupling shaft« on page 51.
 Check the PTO shaft and the connector for dirt or damage.
 Push in the safety lock on the connector.
 Slide the connector on the PTO shaft.
 Release the safety lock.
 Check if the safety plate latches by moving the connector.
 Attach the check chains to both outer edges of the coupling shaft protection sleeves.

The control system can drive the spreader in three different ways:
· distribution that resembles the settings for the preset application rate must be determined under changing circumstances through automatic calibration and driving speed correction,
 see the paragraph below,»Constant application rate«.
with similar or lower application rates (< 40 kg/min) the fine application kit should be used,
 See paragraph »Fine application« on page 67.
· with very low application rates on very uneven terrain, preset application rates must be checked manually to ensure that the correct dosing setting is being distributed, without automatic calibration but with driving speed correction,
· under changing circumstances location specific application rate driven by an external signal, through automatic calibration and driving speed correction,
 See paragraph »Variable, externally driven application rate« on page 72.
The control system can spread an equal amount of fertiliser over the entire field. In doing so, the control system corrects changes in driving speed, while maintaining the option to adjust the application rate manually for over- or underdosing.
The control system can search for the correct dosing setting with the preset application rate through automatic calibration. The disadvantage is that the application rate for the second automatic calibration (= approx. 2 minutes) could differ markedly from the selected application rate. It is therefore strongly recommended that the starting values be taken from the spreading charts. This can be done in the 'Curve Calibration' screen. The control system calculates the discharge curve from the starting values. The control system corrects the spreader for changing circumstances, based on this curve, e.g. as a result of changes in driving speed.
 See also paragraph »The ISO control system« on page 30.
Look for the most comparable fertiliser type and the correct settings for the selected working width in the (online) spreading chart:
 Read the setting of the dosing in the Dosing Setting column that goes with the selected application rate and driving speed.
 The corresponding flowrate is given in the Kg/min column.
 The given values are to be entered in the control system.

The machine has been assembled and delivered ready-for-use by the dealer. The dealer is also responsible for providing instructions for use and maintenance. He/she must also ensure that the required documents are provided, such as:
· manual,
· spare parts manual,
· spreading chart book,
· testing and approval documents where required.
If parts are missing or have been damaged during transport, you should report this to your dealer directly on delivery.
Before the machine can be used, various parts and supplied accessories must be unpacked and assembled.
TIP In addition to the assembly instructions, use the parts book to locate the parts and their positions on the machine.
[Image]
Use sturdy hoisting equipment
Use the hoisting points on the machine to hook up your approved slings or hoisting chains. If the machine is hoisted incorrectly or with inferior equipment it could fall from the sling, resulting in material damage and possible physical injury.
Work on a clean surface
Before you start mounting, you should clean the surface and the directly surrounding area where you place the machine. A machine that is placed on pieces of packaging or parts, may slide away during mounting with material damage and possibly physical injury as a result.
Accessories and parts must be correctly mounted
Assemble accessories and parts according to specifications and attach them only for their designated purpose; ensure that it is locked correctly. Accessories and parts which are not fastened securely could lead to personal injury and damage to the crop and machine.
Tighten all bolts and nuts
Check that all the nuts and bolts are well set. Check this again after one hour of use
· after delivery and
· after maintenance or repairs have been carried out.
Never check holes to be lined up by inserting your fingers
Use a pin. Movement of the machine or parts may cause severe physical injury.

results.question: What torque (in NM) should be applied to the vane lock nuts?
results.model_answer: The correct answer is: 50NM.

results.question: What determines the machine's working width?
results.model_answer:
The working width of a spreader is determined by the coupling shaft connection point on the central gearbox. The position of the discharge point combined with the position of the coupling shaft on the central gearbox, the PTO speed and the flowrate determines the spreading pattern.
The position that would most likely provide the best spreading pattern is given in the third column, Discharge Point, of the spreading chart.
The working width of a spreader can be set between positions C to U. The correct settings are determined on the basis of the selected application rate and the required driving speed.

results.question: Where should the position sensor for the hydraulic border spreading plate be connected?
results.expected_answer: In the electronic box on the spreader.
results.model_answer: The position sensor for the hydraulic border spreading plate is to be connected to the machine electronics.

results.question: What specific precaution should be taken before working between the tractor and machine to check the coupling shaft length?
results.expected_answer: Place the machine on a supporting beam.
results.model_answer: The correct answer is: Check the coupling shaft length.

results.question: What is the maximum operating angle of the coupling shaft when lifted and when lowered?
results.expected_answer: The maximum operating angle of the coupling shaft is 30° when lifted and 30° when lowered.
results.model_answer: The maximum operating angle of the coupling shaft is 30° when lifted and 30° when lowered.

results.question: Should the parking brake of the tractor be engaged before connecting the machine?
results.model_answer: The parking brake of the tractor should be engaged before connecting the machine.

results.question: What is the maximum permissible operating angle in degrees for the coupling shaft, both when lifted and lowered?
results.model_answer: The maximum permissible operating angle of the coupling shaft is 30° when lifted and 30° when lowered.

results.question: What must be ensured with decoupling ropes during power lift connection?
results.expected_answer: Decoupling ropes must never be tense.
results.model_answer: The correct answer is: The coupling shaft must not be connected or disconnected while the PTO shaft is operated externally.

results.question: Below which application rate in kg/min is it advised to use the fine application?
results.model_answer:
The correct answer is: 3.7 kg/min.

results.question: After disengaging the PTO shaft, what poses a continued danger and why?
results.model_answer:

After switching off the PTO shaft, there is a risk of the machine continuing to run because of inertia. The moving parts will continue running for some time after the tractor has been switched off.

results.question: What happens when hopper content falls below 100 kg?
results.model_answer:
If the hopper content is less than 100 kg, the control system switches off the automatic calibration. Measurement accuracy declines in such a way that new automatic calibration cannot produce a better discharge curve.
The application rate can deviate from the required application rate during border spreading. By spreading the field first, the control system can determine the correct dosing setting and thus spread at the correct application rate, also during border spreading.

results.question: Is one-sided boundary spreading suitable for small gardens?
results.model_answer:
The ExactLine is a system of border spreading with a width of 24 metres. It can be used to spread right up to the field edge from the first sprayer tramline.
A ExactLine bends the fertiliser granules in such a way that loss over the edge of the border is restricted to the bare minimum and it provides as full a spreading pattern as possible.
ExactLine has 'environment' and 'yield' settings for precisely adjusting border spreading.
The ExactLine can be used with small working widths, but not with large working widths. The ExactLine is available in a right and a left version.
A trapezoidal spreading pattern may result, depending on the type of fertiliser, working width and application rate.

The ExactLine has an overlapping area of less than 100%.
Reducing working width during the pass
The control of discharge point and dosing via the 4 actuators enables the calculation of a variable working width. By means of this, the working width can be varied at an angle on the headlands (gored spreading) or an incomplete final pass without interrupting the spreading for this purpose.
The spray computer can determine the time of full or partial closure with the GPS and the data of the sprayed passes. This takes place on the headland and during gored spreading. The quantity of over or under fertilisation is substantially reduced by this.

results.question: What is the curriculum of the training program agrarians need to complete to be considered competent to operate this machine?
results.model_answer:
The training program for agrarians is designed to provide them with the necessary knowledge and skills to safely and effectively use the Exacta-TLX GEOSPREAD machine. The curriculum includes:
· Familiarisation of the machine
· Understanding of the operating instructions
· Knowledge of the safety regulations
· Familiarisation of the technical specifications
· Familiarisation of the application rate and working width.
The training program is based on the following modules:
1. Machine familiarisation: This module covers the basic knowledge of the machine, including its components, functions and operation.
2. Operating instructions: This module provides the necessary information for operating the Exacta-TLX GEOSPREAD safely and effectively.
3. Safety regulations: This part of the training program is based on the safety requirements for using the machine.
4. Technical specifications: The module covers the technical details of the machine, including its dimensions, weight and power.
5. Application rate and working width: This part of the training program provides the necessary information for setting the spreader to the correct application rate and working width.
6. Practical exercises: This module includes practical exercises to practice the operating instructions and safety regulations.
7. Final test: The last part of the training program is a final test to check if the trainee has learned the necessary knowledge and skills.
8. Evaluation: The evaluation of the trainee's performance in the training program.
9. Certification: The certification of the trainee as competent to operate the Exacta-TLX GEOSPREAD machine.

The training program for agrarians is designed to provide them with the necessary knowledge and skills to safely and effectively use the Exacta-TLX GEOSPREAD machine.

The machine is designed to be used with the IsoMatch control box. The IsoMatch Tellus can operate for 8 hours of continuous operation before a typical tractor battery will be flattened.
The spreader has two dosing units, which are controlled by means of the spreader software. By means of weight sensors, the spreader continuously measures the quantity of fertiliser that is being spread. The computer in the distribution box compares these values with the set application rate and corrects as needed by further opening or closing the dosing unit.
The tractor's electronics or an extra (GPS) sensor measures the current required driving speed and localisation.
The working width and the start/stop time is controlled with field boundaries and headlands. Field data imported from a new management system or a newly created field boundary is used for this purpose.

When using the ExactLine, drive with the tractor along the field edge and spread from the border inwards. The working width on the side of the field edge can be adjusted by changing the ExactLine position.
The maximum acceptable loss over the field edge is determined by environmental standards. In order to comply with the standard the quantity of fertiliser spread beyond the field edge must be a maximum of 10% of the quantity distributed in the centre behind the spreader (= 100%). Test if the border spreading plate (optional extra) door de test therefore always before hand as described in
 paragraph »Testing the spreading pattern of the hydraulic border spreading plate« on page 84.
The (online) spreading charts indicate the correct setting for the ExactLine and the relevant rpm for the PTO shaft and the spreading discs.
If the settings of the ExactLine are not given in the relevant spreading chart they can be obtained in the following sources:
· find with the online spreading chart service on the website or via the Free Application (App) for mobile phones with an iOs and/or Android operating system.
 See paragraph »Online spreading chart service« on page 61.
Always check the settings of the ExactLine by performing the test as described in
 paragraph »Testing ExactLine spreading pattern« on page 90.
The type of fertiliser is determined when adjusting the spreader, as described in
 paragraph »Determine the type and pattern of the granules« on page 58.
you can choose from 3 settings from the chart:
· YIELD.
· ECO,
In the yield setting (YIELD), the loss over the field edge is higher than what is allowed by the environmental standard. Therefore, never use this setting next to surface water. Cover to the border is very good with this option.
The loss over the field edge will be equal to or less than the environment standard in the environment setting (ECO). Always use this setting when working next to a surface water! The result is that the cover at the border of the property is not optimum.
 See the software instruction manual.

Use in the field
Checking the hydraulic system
[Image]
[Image]
Hydraulic oil is under high pressure
Never try to stop a leak with your fingers. Never try to locate a hydraulic leak or try to contain it by hand! When inspecting always use appropriate aid (e.g. a piece of wood or sheet metal) and wear safety goggles, safety gloves and gloves! High pressure fluid easily penetrates skin and clothes, causing severe injuries. In the event of injury, contact your physician immediately!
Do not exceed the maximum hydraulic pressure of 210 bars
Prevent the pressure in the hydraulic system from exceeding 210 bars! Working above the permitted pressure may damage your machine and result in dangerous situations.
Keep your distance from the hydraulics during inspecting and test running
Use a stick to bend the hydraulic hoses when checking them for leakage. That way you will keep at sufficient distance. Oil jets or hoses that snap back may cause serious physical injury due to the prevailing pressure and temperature.
Work safely on the hydraulic system
The hydraulic system could be under high pressure. Do not work on the hydraulic system without:
· releasing the pressure from the hydraulic system,
· switching off the electronic control system,
· switching the tractor off,
· the key must be removed from the ignition,
· engage the parking brake of the tractor,
· using the proper tools,
· wear safety glasses, gloves and shoes.
Working in an unsafe manner on the hydraulic system could lead to injury and damage to the machine. In the event of injury, contact your physician immediately! There is also the risk of infection!
Before operating the hydraulic system, check all connections and hoses for damage and leakage.
Regularly inspect the hydraulic system (hoses, pipes, connections). All hoses, piping and connecting points must be checked regularly, but at least once a year, by an expert for leakages or visible damage! The lifetime of a hose should be 6 years maximum (see the production date on the hoses).
Damaged or old parts must be replaced with new ones that comply with the technical specifications of the manufacturer of the machine. Damage to the hydraulic system could lead to injury.

Use in the field
Checking the hydraulic system
[Image]
[Image]
Hydraulic oil is under high pressure
Never try to stop a leak with your fingers. Never try to locate a hydraulic leak or try to contain it by hand! When inspecting always use appropriate aid (e.g. a piece of wood or sheet metal) and wear safety goggles, safety gloves and gloves! High pressure fluid easily penetrates skin and clothes, causing severe injuries. In the event of injury, contact your physician immediately!
Do not exceed the maximum hydraulic pressure of 210 bars
Prevent the pressure in the hydraulic system from exceeding 210 bars! Working above the permitted pressure may damage your machine and result in dangerous situations.
Keep your distance from the hydraulics during inspecting and test running
Use a stick to bend the hydraulic hoses when checking them for leakage. That way you will keep at sufficient distance. Oil jets or hoses that snap back may cause serious physical injury due to the prevailing pressure and temperature.
Work safely on the hydraulic system
The hydraulic system could be under high pressure. Do not work on the hydraulic system without:
· releasing the pressure from the hydraulic system,
· switching off the electronic control system,
· switching the tractor off,
· the key must be removed from the ignition,
· engage the parking brake of the tractor,
· using the proper tools,
· wear safety glasses, gloves and shoes.
Working in an unsafe manner on the hydraulic system could lead to injury and damage to the machine. In the event of injury, contact your physician immediately! There is also the risk of infection!
Before operating the hydraulic system, check all connections and hoses for damage and leakage.
Regularly inspect the hydraulic system (hoses, pipes, connections). All hoses, piping and connecting points must be checked regularly, but at least once a year, by an expert for leakages or visible damage! The lifetime of a hose should be 6 years maximum (see the production date on the hoses).
